name: Thimphu
fun_fact: Fun fact: Thimphu is the world's only capital city with no traffic lights! Traffic is managed by vigilant policemen wearing white gloves who direct vehicles at major intersections. In 1998, Bhutan removed a trial traffic light simply because people preferred relying on officersâ€”residents felt the impersonal nature of traffic lights didn't suit the communal and human-centric ethos of Bhutanese society. Bhutan also prioritizes Gross National Happiness (GNH) over GDP and is the world's first and only carbon-negative nation!

hero_dishes.name: Ema Datshi (Chili Cheese Stew)
hero_dishes.description: Bhutan's national dishâ€”a spicy stew made from hot chili peppers and cheese (datshi). 'Ema' means chili and 'datshi' means cheese in Dzongkha. Bhutanese eat this almost every day with red rice.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Often called the 'soul of Bhutanese cuisine,' Ema Datshi represents more than foodâ€”it embodies culture, traditions, and agricultural simplicity of Bhutan. What makes it unique is its widespread presence: served at humble family dinners and grand celebratory feasts alike. The cheese (datshi) is made from goat, cow, or yak's milk. This dish showcases the Bhutanese love for extremely spicy foodâ€”chilies are treated as a vegetable, not just a seasoning!
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Folk Heritage Restaurant (Thimphu) for authentic preparation with traditional ambiance, Bukhari at COMO Uma (Paro) for fine-dining twist, Central Market Stalls (Thimphu) for budget-friendly home-style versions, Choki Traditional Art School CafÃ© (Thimphu)

hero_dishes.name: Kewa Datshi (Potato Cheese)
hero_dishes.description: Popular variation of Ema Datshi using potatoes instead of just chiliesâ€”still spicy but more accessible to those not used to extreme heat
hero_dishes.origin_story: Kewa Datshi represents how Bhutanese cuisine adapts while maintaining its core identityâ€”the beloved datshi (cheese). Potatoes soften the intense chili heat while still providing substantial spice. It's comfort food for Bhutanese people.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Every Bhutanese restaurant, home kitchens, hotel dining rooms

hero_dishes.name: Phaksha Paa (Pork with Red Chilies)
hero_dishes.description: Dried pork cooked with red chilies and sometimes radishesâ€”a rich, fatty, spicy dish
hero_dishes.origin_story: Pork is popular in Bhutan, and this dish showcases the Bhutanese method of preserving meat through drying. The dried pork (shakam) is rehydrated during cooking, creating intensely flavored, fatty pieces that pair perfectly with rice and cut through the altitude's cold.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Bhutanese restaurants, farmhouse homestays, local eateries in Thimphu

hero_dishes.name: Red Rice with Ema Datshi
hero_dishes.description: Bhutan's staple grainâ€”short-grain red rice with a nutty flavor, always served with Ema Datshi and other curries
hero_dishes.origin_story: Red rice grows in the Paro Valley and is semi-milled, retaining nutrients in the red husk. It's higher in fiber than white rice and has a distinctive nutty, earthy flavor. Bhutanese consider a meal incomplete without rice, and red rice is the premium variety.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Every Bhutanese meal, markets selling local Paro Valley red rice

hero_dishes.name: Jasha Maroo (Spicy Chicken Curry)
hero_dishes.description: Minced chicken cooked with tomatoes, ginger, garlic, and lots of chiliesâ€”another spicy staple
hero_dishes.origin_story: Jasha Maroo shows how Bhutanese cuisine balances meat, vegetables, and intense spice. The chicken is finely minced or shredded, allowing the spices to penetrate thoroughly. It's often served alongside Ema Datshi for a complete meal.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Bhutanese restaurants, hotel dining rooms, local family eateries

signature_drinks.name: Suja (Butter Tea)
signature_drinks.description: Traditional Bhutanese tea made by blending tea with yak butter and saltâ€”high calorie, smooth, hot, and healthy
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The most well-known beverage in Bhutan, especially in colder areas. The word suja means 'su' (churned) and 'ja' (chai/tea). Traditionally churned in a wooden device called a dapa for perfect consistency, made using yak butter prized for its high fat content. Unlike sweet teas, Suja is salty, slightly smoky, and deeply nourishing. It's more than a beverageâ€”it's an offering, a social ritual, and a gesture of hospitality. Drunk at special occasions like weddings and Losar (Tibetan New Year). When being hosted, guests are typically served Suja along with Zao (puffed rice roasted with butter and sugar). This tradition dates back to the 7th century.

signature_drinks.name: Ara (Traditional Rice Spirit)
signature_drinks.description: Traditional alcoholic liquor made from fermented or distilled rice, wheat, millet, buckwheat, maize, or barleyâ€”clear and strong, sometimes with butter and eggs added for flavor
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: A significant part of Bhutan's social and cultural foundation. Usually made by hand, commonly prepared at home by women. Ara is a huge part of the country's cultural heritage, stored in traditional flasks. It's drunk during celebrations, festivals, and social gatherings. Stronger than chang (millet beer) because it's distilled.

signature_drinks.name: Ngaja (Sweet Milk Tea)
signature_drinks.description: Sweet milk tea similar to Indian chai, but with Bhutanese preparation methods
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The sweeter alternative to salty butter tea. Both teas can be enjoyed with zaw (puffed rice) or sip (pounded corn). More common in modern Thimphu cafÃ©s and restaurants than traditional suja.
